Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, the soft hum of the air conditioner blending with the distant laughter of my child in the living room. Today was supposed to be a day of rest, just us at home, and I had planned to wear my most comfortable pajamas—short sleeves and loose pants, nothing fancy, just comfort. But as I reached for them, I hesitated. Even though it was just my immediate family, I remembered the teachings about modesty, about always dressing in a way that reflects my faith, even in private settings. 

At the same time, my mind kept drifting to the promise I made to my child last month: a Nintendo for their birthday. Money was tight, and I knew buying it would mean cutting back on groceries or skipping a bill. But the look of hope in my child’s eyes haunted me. I felt pulled in two directions—wanting to fulfill my promise as a parent, to see my child’s joy, and wanting to honor my faith, to be a good Muslim in every aspect of my life. The weight of these expectations pressed down on me, and I sat there, torn, unsure which role to honor first.
